results.title: Naked intent
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Chris Begley
results.brief_description: A loose door number on a hotel room leads to surprises all round when novelty stripper Ralph Little finds himself performing for a gang of jewel thieves, all the while being watched by police surveillance - courtesy of a stuffed koala with a hidden camera.

results.title: Naked
results.creator_credit: Thin Man Productions, British Screen, Film Four International, Simon Channing-Williams and Mike Leigh
results.brief_description: Director Mike Leigh’s films have explored the dynamics of class relations in Britain for over two decades. The release of “Naked” saw a controversy erupt over the bleak and distressing vision he presents of post-Thatcherite class and gender relations. “Naked” is a descent into Hell. We follow the homeless Johnny on an Odyssey through the streets of London; a journey in which he confronts loneliness, violence and hate. Johnny is no hero. Violent with women and a destroyer of fantasy, he is presented with a chilling candour that can be seen as misanthropic. His life is contrasted with the excessive greed of the yuppie Jermey/Sebastian whose wealth allows him the luxury of a security that is no longer possible for Johnny. “Naked” is a masterpiece of contemporary cinema and one of the most harrowing and confronting films ever made; a film that simultaneously smashes the romantic pieties of social-realist cinema and reinvigorates the possibilities of political filmmaking. David Thewlis is brilliant as Johnny, and he is supported by an exceptional cast. Winner of Best Director and Best Actor (David Thewlis) awards at the 1993 Cannes Film Festival.

results.title: Naissance du Parlant (1928-1930) Pt. 01
results.brief_description:
Part 1 of a 13 part series on the history of French cinema. By 1927, it’s official: the cinema speaks! The premiere of the ‘Jazz Singer’ in New York catches the French studios unprepared and the filmmakers unwilling to accept with this technical revolution. While the studios rush to re-equip and sound-proof their facilities, filmmakers embark on a local polemic regarding the artistic set back represented by sound. Their arguements are simple: prisonner of the linguistic barriers, ‘talkies’ will loose their universality ; the camera, which the ‘Avant-Garde’ had tamed and made mobile, is now static and enslaved to the demands of sound recording. Furthermore, the only sound recording systems are foreign: Tobis-Klang Film in Berlin or Western Electric and RCA in the USA. French filmmakers make, at first, a rather gimmicky use of the sound process, (the first sound heard in a French film is that of bath being emptied) until a little mouse convince them that sound can be used intelligently to serve the dramaturgy. Yes! Mickey Mouse imposes the ‘talkies’ in France. Ironically, it was Rene Clair, one of the most vociferous opponents of sound, who directed the first great French sound film, ‘Sous les toits de Paris’, at the Epinay studios in 1930. Although the film did manifest an adventurous use of sound - privileging songs while reducing dialogue to a minimum, and including some counterpoint experiments, in which sound and image were not synchronised - it was most notable for Lazare Meerson’s set design, which evoked a realistic yet lyrical picture of working-class Paris.” Reference: Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French cinema’. Manchester University Press, 1996. Further viewing: ‘Le silence est d’or’ (Rene Clair, 1947). Further reading: Richard Abel. “French cinema: the first wave, 1915-1929’. Princeton University Press, 1984. *=Held in our collection.

Credits: Director, Armand Panigel ; photography, Claude Cassard.
Includes interviews with Rene Clair, Marcel L’Herbier, Abel Gance, Marcel Pagnol, Jean-Paul Le Chanois, Marcel Carne.

results.title: Naissance du Jour = Retreat from Love (TV Version)
results.brief_description:
Summer 1928. As usual Colette settles for the summer in her beloved country house to enjoy the earthly pleasures of Provence, the company of her artist friends and time to write. Now in her 50’s, the writer is offered a last chance at love by a much younger man, Vial. Vial is also wanted by a newcomer to Colette’s circle, Helene Clement. ‘La naissance du jour’ is a biographical account of Colette’s slow acceptance of age and renouncement to love. Filmed on location at ‘La treille muscate’, Colette’s house in St Tropez.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Baraduc ; director, Jacques Demy ; writer, Jacques Demy ; photography, Jean Penzer ; music, Mendelsohn.
Cast: Daniele Delorme, Jean Sorel, Dominique Sanda, Orane Demazis.

results.title: Nails = Les Clous = Die Nagel
results.creator_credit: International Film Bureau and Kurt Aeschbacher
results.brief_description: An abstract statement on the problem of over population. A community of nails busily propagates, builds and spreads within a limited area. Eventually there is no more area for living and the nails rust and corrode. Music by Bruno Spoerri.

results.title: Nails
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, John Taylor and Phillip Borsos
results.brief_description: A non-narrated look at the manufacture of nails, juxtaposing highly mechanised factory production with the slower outputs of a small business and a single blacksmith. The blacksmith is seen labouring at his forge, shaping nails from single strands of steel rods. The scene shifts from this peaceful setting to the roar of a twentieth century mill, where banks of machines draw, cut and pound the steel rods faster than the eye can follow. These diametrically opposed scenes emphasise the changed relationship between the individual and his work. (Awards: New York, Chicago, Toronto)

results.title: Nahanni
results.brief_description: The legend of a lost gold mine and a river in the Northwest Territories that lures men to their doom. Albert Faille, an aging prospector from Fort Simpson, has set out time after time to find hidden gold. His route is through a wild, awesome land particularly suited to the mood of this Canadian odyssey.

results.title: Nah - he was in a big house before (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: La Trobe University. Centre for the Study of Educational Communication and Media, Patricia Edgar and Dave McRae
results.brief_description: The experiences of a teacher in his first year of teaching in a country high school. Investigates the town, the people, and the activities of the township, and then looks at the school and the problems concerning teachers in the school, with particular reference to his own experience in his first year. Written and directed by Dave McRae.

results.title: Nadja
results.creator_credit: Kino Link Company, Mary Sweeney, Amy Hobby and Michael Almereyda
results.brief_description:
Revisiting the vampire legend director/writer Michael Almereyda creates a modern day setting for several sexy undead creatures of the night. Elina Lowensohn plays the title role - a New York based vampire who is celebrating the demise of her father, and is hoping that her new life will encompass the attractive Lucy. Unfortunately Lucy is married to the nephew of a vampire hunter who is hell-bent on conquering Nadja. Aesthetically the film is an alluring mix of 35 mm footage and black-and-white, low-budget Pixelvision video.
